etymology_text: Onomatopoeic, of regional Mediterranean origin and cognate to Ancient Greek ἀτταταί, ἀτταταταί (attataí, attatataí).

examples.text: Attat eccam, adest propinquē!
examples.english: Aha, there she is right over there!

glosses: An expression of sudden enlightenment, surprise or painful realisation aha, hey, oh no!

examples.english: "No, wait!" I say, "don't write this - they don't want to hear it."

examples.text: Fi, fi fetet!

categories.name: Latin entries with incorrect language header
Latin prepositions

etymology_text: From Old Latin ne (“not”), from Proto-Italic *nē, from the extension of Proto-Indo-European *ne (“not”). Cognates include Proto-Germanic *ne (whence Gothic 𐌽𐌹 (ni) and Old English ne), Sanskrit न (ná), Bulgarian, Serbo-Croatian and Russian не (ne), Lithuanian ne, Irish ní.

examples.text: Vereor, nē videātur ōrātiō mea stulta.
examples.english: I fear lest my oration seem foolish.

examples.text: nē quem post sē hostem reliqueret
examples.ref: c. 52 BCE, Julius Caesar, Commentarii de Bello Gallico 7.11
examples.english: in order not to leave any enemy behind himself

examples.text: sī reliquam partem hiemis ūnō locō legiōnēs continēret, nē stipendiāriīs Aeduōrum expugnātīs cūncta Gallia dēficeret
examples.ref: c. 52 BCE, Julius Caesar, Commentarii de Bello Gallico 7.10
examples.english: [he feared] lest if he should confine his legions in one place for the remaining part of the winter, all Gaul would revolt when the stipendiaries of the Aedui were subdued

examples.text: veritus nē noctū ex oppidō prōfugerent
examples.ref: c. 52 BCE, Julius Caesar, Commentarii de Bello Gallico 7.11
examples.english: he feared lest [the enemy] should escape by night

glosses: that not, in order not to and similar; lest

etymology_text: From Cato the Elder's practice of ending every speech, no matter the topic, with ceterum censeo Carthaginem esse delendam ("furthermore, I propose that Carthage is to be destroyed").

glosses: "furthermore, I propose": a formulaic expression used to end a speech by reinforcing one, often unrelated, major view

etymology_text: From Proto-Italic *-pe, from Proto-Indo-European *pe. Cognate with Luwian -pa, Luwian ppa-, and Lithuanian kaĩp (“how”).

glosses: used in the formation of certain words as an intensive particle

categories.name: Latin entries with incorrect language header
Latin particles
Luwian terms in nonstandard scripts

etymology_text: From Proto-Italic *-kʷe (“and”), from Proto-Indo-European *-kʷe (“and”). Cognates include Sanskrit च (ca), Ancient Greek τε (te), Proto-Germanic *-hw ( → English (thou)gh). Its alternative use as a generalizing particle "any, -every" with pronouns and adverbs may result from a shift from an earlier meaning along the lines of "as". There are also a number of words that are etymologically suffixed with this particle but that have developed specific meanings not clearly analyzable in terms of either of these senses, such as dēnique (“finally; at length”).

examples.text: quis (“who”) + -que (“-ever”) → quisque (“whoever; anyone; each one”)
cum (“when”) + -que (“-ever”) → cumque (“whenever; however”)
ubī (“where”) + -que (“-ever”) → ubīque (“wherever, anywhere, everywhere”)

glosses: -ever; every-, any-; every, each ('universalizing' or 'generalizing' particle found in a fixed set of indefinite pronouns and adverbs)

related.word: † Turned conjunction with original meaning somewhat dissimulated° Rare‡only used as a conjunction

word: de gustibus et coloribus non est disputandum

sounds.ipa: /deː ˈɡus.ti.bus et koˈloː.ri.bus noːn est dis.puˈtan.dum/
[d̪eː ˈɡʊs̠t̪ɪbʊs̠ ɛt̪ kɔˈɫ̪oːrɪbʊs̠ noːn ɛs̠t̪ d̪ɪs̠pʊˈt̪än̪d̪ʊ̃ˑ]
/de ˈɡus.ti.bus et koˈlo.ri.bus non est dis.puˈtan.dum/

examples.text: De gustibus et coloribus non est disputandum—certainly not with a lady. We shall be glad to know, however, if the opinion of our fair and candid correspondent is generally shared.—Ed.
examples.ref: 1883, Monthly Notes Of The Library Association of the United Kingdom, volume 4, number 2 (in English), page 40

glosses: Alternative form of dē gustibus nōn est disputandum (“there's no accounting for taste”)

categories.name: Ecclesiastical Latin
Latin entries with incorrect language header
Time

examples.text: Munera, quæsumus, Domine, suscipe placatus; & me famulum tuum semper, & ubique misericorditer protege. Per Dominum.
examples.ref: 1704 [1563], Giovanni Paolo Lancelotti, Institutiones Iuris Canonici de Mandato Pauli Papae IV, Venice, column 383
examples.english: Peaceably receive the gifts, we beseech you, Lord, and always and everywhere mercifully protect me, your servant. Through our Lord …

examples.text: Beatæ et gloriosæ semper virginis Mariæ, quæsumus, Domine, intercessio gloriosa nos protegat, et ad vitam perducat æternam. Per Dominum.
examples.ref: 1838, Breviarium Romanum […], Lyon and Paris, Officium Parvum Beatae Mariae, ad Completorium, Oratio, page 100*
examples.english: We beseech you, Lord, that the glorious intercession of the blessed and glorious ever-virgin Mary protect us, and lead us to eternal life. Through our Lord …

examples.text: Obláta, Dómine, múnera sanctífica: nosque a peccatórum nostrórum máculis emúnda. Per Dóminum.
examples.ref: 1958, Saint Andrew Daily Missal, with Vespers for Sundays and Feasts, Second Sunday after the Epiphany, Secret, page 130
examples.english: Sanctify, Lord, the gifts which we offer: and cleanse us from the stains of our sins. Through our Lord …

glosses: Written abbreviation of “per Dominum nostrum Iesum Christum Filium tuum, qui tecum vivit et regnat in unitate Spiritus Sancti, Deus, per omnia saecula saeculorum” (“through our Lord Jesus Christ your Son, who lives and reigns with you in the unity of the Holy Spirit, God, for ever and ever”), a standard conclusion to a liturgical prayer.

etymology_text:
From Old Latin olle (“he, that”) (also ollus, olla), from Proto-Italic *olnos, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂ol-no-s or *h₂l̥-no-s, from *h₂el- (“beyond, other”). Cognate with Latin uls (“beyond”), alius (“other”), and alter (“the other”); Umbrian ulu (“to that place”), Old Church Slavonic лани (lani, “last year”, literally “in that (year)”).
Initial i- from o- has no parallel case and may be owing to contamination from is, iste or due to the palatalizing effect of l exilis.

etymology_templates.name: cog
etymology_templates.expansion: Old Church Slavonic лани (lani, “last year”, literally “in that (year)”)

etymology_text: From grātus (“pleasing”). Related to Sanskrit गूर्ति (gūrtí, “praise, welcome, benediction”).

Equivalent to an adverbial derivation from *ēregō, presumably ex- + regō, with sense similar to cognate pergō (“I proceed”).
See also ergā. Compare with the adverbial use of ē regiōne (“directly, against”), with the same elements.

etymology_text:
Adopted from the thematic vowel in Ancient Greek -ο- (-o-) and -ό- (-ó-), often used to form nominal compounds. In Ancient Greek, the connective suffix originates in compounds where the first member is thematic, such as δημοκρατία (dēmokratía), but was extended by analogy to other stems, such as μητρόπολις (mētrópolis). The suffix was borrowed as a connective into Latin, mainly in compounds of Greek origin.
The suffix becomes productive and forms new compounds in learned humanist Latin, from the Renaissance. The connective is especially productive in connecting ethnonyms or geographical terms; genuine Greek stems include Gallo-, and Syro-, but most are of medieval or modern origin, productive from the 15th century, such as Anglo-, Graeco- or Latino-.

raw_glosses: (post-classical Latin) Suffix forming nominal compounds (such as anglosaxonicus (“Anglo-Saxon”), from Anglus (“Angle, English”) and saxonicus (“Saxon”)).
glosses: Suffix forming nominal compounds (such as anglosaxonicus (“Anglo-Saxon”), from Anglus (“Angle, English”) and saxonicus (“Saxon”)).

categories.name: Latin entries with incorrect language header
Latin interfixes

etymology_text: From the reduction of several historical unstressed short stem vowels during the Old Latin period. The reduced vowel was later reinterpreted as part of various suffixes.

glosses: Connecting vowel inserted between a stem and a suffix in compound words.

categories.name: Latin entries with incorrect language header
Latin interfixes

examples.text: accubō (“I lie”) + -n- → accumbō (“I recline, lie down”)

glosses: Infix used to denote an action (not lasting); becomes -m- in front of b, m, p

categories.name: Latin entries with incorrect language header

examples.text: iugō (“I tie”) + -n- → iungō (“I tie for a long time”)
coniugō (“I tie firmly”) + -n- → coniungō (“I tie firmly for a long time”)

glosses: Infix used to denote a lasting action; becomes -m- in front of b, m, p
